text:
Pours a deep opaque chocolate brown with thick nitro off white head that totally coats the glass as I drink it down. Roasty aroma. Light bodied dry, roasty but clean, chocolately with a bakers chocolate bitterness. 

Notes: on tap at the brew pub, June 17

Draught at RRBC. Black color, beige head. Bitter with roasted malts, nuts, smoke, espresso, chocolate and licorice. Bitter finish with roasted malts, smoke, espresso, nuts, chocolate and licorice. Excellent stout, huge flavor profile for such low ABV.
Draft. During my bachelor party long weekend in the san francisco area, sixth stop(day 1) RR. Dark pour with light head. Roasted, light coffee, dry malt tones.

From tap at the brewery. Black color with beige brown head. Roasted malty aroma, bread, grainy, coffee, some chocolate notes. Light sweet and moderate to heavy bitter taste. Medium oily body with soft carbonation.

Sort skum tæt lang cremet 
Kaffe malt tømmer 
Bitter modrTe sød lidt 
Cremet /Olie blød
On tap at Russian River. Comes almost black with a nice tan head. Aroma of chocolate and malt. Taste is chocolate, roasted malt, and some coffee. It is a dry stout. Tasty.
Draft at the source. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate and roasted malts. Taste is chocolate, roasted malts, coffee notes. Dry finish. A little thin.
Aroma: roasty; Appearance: very dark amber with tan head that lingers; Taste: dry, roasty, and slightly dank; smooth; Palate: medium body; Overall: very good.
Tap at the brewpub. Pours black. Clearly a dry stout, as it is actually dry. Some roasted burnt tones, but not highly distinguished. Bitter, very. Also works, but really not my favourite.

Draught at Russian River, Santa Rosa. Black beer with a nice beige head. Roasted dark chocolate aroma, cacao nibs, licorice, some tar. Chocolate flavor, licorice, cacao nibs, some tar. Lots of flavors for the ABV.
Dark cola brown pour with a clumpy khaki head. Greasy dark roast nose. Flat. Watery.
August 3, 2016 - on tap at RRBC. Black pour with nice head and thick lacing. Aroma of chocolate and roast. Taste was like a coffee with chocolate. Palate was a bit thin.
Sample at brewery. Great chocolate and roasted malt nose. Taste and mouth feel like a heavier Guinness. Very good.

On tap at Russian River Brewing in Santa Rosa, CA-USA. Pours coffee bean color, nice brownish head. Nose: bitter coffee, coffee shake frappe. Mouth: mirrors the nose, bitter distinctive finish, watery. Nice!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draught @ Russian River Brewing, Santa Rosa, California (20.04.2016)  

Ogromna kremowa piana. Oleista, potężna zwarta tekstura. W smaku i zapachu dominuje bardzo intensywna kawa z mlekiem. Prócz tego orzeszki ziemne, lekka mleczność, laktoza. Paloność idealnie współgra z czekoladą. Lekko ściągający finisz. Dobry trunek, nic poza tym.

Tap to glass @ Russian River Brewing tap room@ Santa Rosa,CA
A: Black/dark brown if held agains the light, big brown head lacing
A: nutty, with a hint of chocolate
T: not bold, not a lot of taste
MF: slightly creamy, fizzy
OA: Good stout- ok to repeat, not buy, not look forward to
Drank: April 14, 2016 9pm
@ Russian River 16-3-7: En riktig stilenlig Irsk stout med starkt rostat kaffe och lite bitter choklad. Mycket torr.
On tap at RR. Poured black with off white head. Aroma classic choc dark roast malt. Light carb med bod. Taste dull roast oat. Not alot going on.

Nitro draft to taster at the brewpub. Looks good; a translucent cola with creamy light beige head. Smells of dark malt, chocolate, and roast with a distinctly dry stout nose. Tastes like it smells with a fairly dry medium light-bodied mouthfeel. Some bitterness from the roast as well. Okay.

Draft at the Russian river brewpub. Opaque black / mahogany brown coloured pour with a creamy light tam head. Aroma is light ashy roast, light dried fruit, earthy roast. Flavour is composed of tangy roasted malts, nutty, light ashy coffee roast. Palate is semi creamy. Moderate, carbonation, bitter choc, little stale coffee.
On tap at the brewery. Pours a cloudy brown with medium frothy beige head that lasts. The aroma is cracker malt, cocoa, roast. Thin mouth, light roast, chocolate, light dry finish, good.

Pours a deep brownish black on tap with fluffy lasting tan head. Aroma and taste of dark malts, nice chocolate notes, and faint earth. Nice flavorful version of the style with the good creamy nitro mouth.
Tap poured crimson black with a frothy tan head and lacing. Aromas of roasted chocolate malts, coffee, and caramel. Flavor is a bit watery, medium bitter.

Taster @ Russian Rivers Brewing, Santa Rosa - CA. Color: deep dark black beer with no carbonation and small brown head. Smell: roasted malt and coffee. Notes of caramel and hoppy. Taste: light body with roasted malt and coffee, chocolate notes. Good balance with hops. Good dry grassy finish. Aftertaste: coffee and chocolate with grassy bitterness.

Draft to taster at RR brewpub
Toasted malt, coffee, caramel, dark chocolate. Dark brown with a creamy tan head with great retention. Lacing is quite thick and it costs the glass uniformly. Taste is toasted malt which gets broken up by a sour then bitter finish.

Sampler at the brewpub in Santa Rosa. Dry coffee, bitter, some roasted aromas. Taste is similar, on the dry side, a bit chalk and cocoa powder. Low carbonation (hand pump?). It has - like many Stouts - a slightly watery mouthfeel. Still nice though.

3 oz chilled pour from tap into cylindrical taster as part of Russian Rivers everything on tap sampled (16 beers this time around) at the brewery itself. I realize that drinking 16 different 3 oz pours is not ideal for proper rating, but when will I ever have an opportunity like this again?

The nitro kept the head around for thirty minutes. As dry Irish stouts go, Id say its one of the best Ive had. Tastes a lot like cocoa powder or bakers chocolate.

Draught at the Russian River Brewing Co, Santa Rosa, CA.
Dark reddish brown colour with a mid-size tan head. 
Roasted malt, mild coffee, milky sweetness and vanilla in the aroma. 
Roasted malt, strong coffee and strong bitterness in the flavour. Bitter and roasted. Watery.
on tap at the brewery; black color; chocolaty, roasted malt aroma; a nice smooth stout with roasted malt flavor and notes of chocolate and coffee; dry finish
This poured a darker brown with a beige head. Aroma was of of lightly roasted malt and grassy hops. Flavor was similar, pretty standard dry stout.

On tap at the brewery. Pours black with a big creamy tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, milk stout-like. Flavor is creamy, irish coffee, and chocolate. Good for an Irish stout. Decent creamy body on it.
Taster at Russian River. Pours black with cream head. Aroma is expresso and coffee. Flavour has a nitro feel but this isn't nitro. Weak coffee and mocha.

Draft at Russian River with Linh. Pours a deep brownish black with thin off white lacing. Aroma is coffee roast and earthy root character. Mouthfeel is medium to full with nice rounded roasty flavor, light coffee, earth and lactose.
On tap scura buone note torrefatte ma piuttosto morbida in bocca amaro medio secchezza media
Weak aroma of coffee, great looking dark brown with a well laced tan head. Weak coffee taste with a watery feel and an espresso finish.
On tap at Russian River. Pour is clear brownish with light tan head..Nose is sweetness, lactose, coffee, soft..Taste is light, chocolate, coffee, spices, lactose, light bitterness
"a pleasant flavor and nice roasted coffee aroma. i think, though, that this beer is not big enough for nitrous...the end product is a tad too watery. other than that, its a textbook dry irish
Toasty malt nose. Dark brown pour with a tan head, tons of lacing. Big roasted malt and bitter chocolate taste with low astringency. Slightly sweet and bitter finish. Nice.

Draft at RRBC. Black, tan nitro head shrinks but never dies. Lovely aromas of ashy dry roast and coffee, some hops. Tastes a tinytouch sweet then dry ash, burnt dark roast, espresso coffee, hop bitterness. Dry finish. Quite thin, light body. Apart from the thin body this is excellent.
Sampler @ RR. Black colour. Coffee and chocolate, light bodied, finishes dry.

6 oz. draft sample at Russian River. Great looking Nitro pour. Aroma is roasted coffee, burnt chocolate malt and caramel sweetness. I sort of remember how Guinness tasted in Ireland when I had it around 1998, Although that was years before people started rating beer on the internet. Anyhow.... that makes me sound and feel old! This stout has a great full body and creaminess with the deep dry roast you want to find in the style. Excellent example of a classic dry stout. And great flavor at 4% ABV stout.

Fad: Taster og kones pint på brewpub. Kulsort på nitro med det lækre cremet skum an får fra nitro. Noterne siger ret tydeligt, som Guiness skulle have været. Verdensklasse dry stout, smooth proppe med smag. Superlækker øl.

On tap at the RR Brewpub in Santa Rosa.

A: dak brow-blackn, essentially opaque but clear. Semi-durable head still leaves very good lacing. 

Aroma: dark roasted malts withfaint hops.

Flavor: dark roastd malts with more obvious hops than in the aroma.

Feel: smooth; light body seemed relatively too light for style and even a bit watery; medium-low carbonation. 

O: OK

Nose fulloif roast and dark chocolate. Medium brown head on a black beer. Taste is a sharp bitter dark coffee. Short of burnt. Very light and drying. A touch of tartness in the finish. Very good. Reminds me a lot of Guinness with that light tartness.

On tap @ Russian River. Pours a deep brown / black appearance with a brown head. Fairly roasty nose. A hint of smoke. Light coffee. Flavor is pretty dry, slightly herbal and chalky with some dark chocolate and coffee. Fine.
On tap at the source. Pour is dark brown/near place. Creamy tan head. Aroma is cocoa and toast. Tastes very roasty with light acid and toasty bitterness.

Draft as part of the full sampler at Russian River. Black with tan head. Aromas of roast, smoke, chocolate. Tastes of tobacco, light smoke, chocolate, roast, caramel, oats. Medium body with a dry finish. Creamy mouthfeel. Nice.

Sampled at the brewery. Pours black with a lingering, beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, light chocolate and coffee notes, some dough, and hints of bitterness. Flavor the same. Average texture for a nitro stout. A pretty good beer.

Draught @ Russian River, Santa Rosa, CA

Pours pitch black with a creamy white head. Aroma of roasty malts, creamy milky notes, cocoa and chocolate. Taste is smopth, creamy and silky with some roastiness, cocoa and chocolate. Finish is smooth and creamy with some milky notes. Smooth and creamy stout.

Keg at Russian River, Santa Rosa, 27/04/14.
Light black with a moderate tan covering that retains well.
Nose is roast malt, dark toffee, light cocoa, faint coffee grinds.
Taste comprises milk chocolate, light roastings, hint of minerals, earthy cocoa, faint coffee.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, smooth on the palate, drying close.
Nice easy drinker, quite a bit more depth to the flavour than your average dry stout - good work!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Sampler at Russian River. Pours dark brown. Very creamy, slight tan head. Quite thin body, very smooth and silky. Almost no carbonation. Sweet and bitter. Chocolate, vanilla, milk, burnt malt flavour. A very good stout. Reminds me of Guinness, but its way better.
Black with khaki head. Chocolate and roasted malt nose. Chocolate, roasted malt, coffee and cream flavors. Medium body and a creamy mouthfeel. Dry finish.
Tasty and smooth stout. Thick and creamy head. A little bit fizzy. Flavour not as strong as some other stouts, making it a little easier drinking.
On tap @ RR! Dark Godiva pour with a frothy latte head. Cocoa, roasted coffee, toasted oats, and a touch of vanilla. Medium mouthfeel. Average.
On tap @ RR. Black with a large tan head. Notes of coffee grounds, chocolate, heavily roasted malts, and toffee. Tart and dry finish.

Tried as part of a sampler at the brewery. This was a black pour with super creamy light brown khaki head. Chocolate and espresso on the aroma, plenty of roast to go along. Surprised at the big aroma for such a light stout. Big chocolate and roasted coffee flavor, finishes with lingering charred roast. This has more flavor than I have had in any dry stout. Nicely done. Very thin mouthfeel that goes down very easy with velvety carb. Not bad at all, and I would have this again despite this being one of my least favorite styles.

On tap at the Brewpub in February 2014. 

Black with a small creamy head. On the sweet side with chocolate, light roasted malt, some coffee and toffee. The mouthfeel was creamy. Quite good.
Sampler at the brewery- Pours mostly black with a nice creamy light mocha head. Aroma is chocolate, nice. The taste is all coffee and chocolate, robust and delicious.
From sampler at the brewery. Dark brown pour. Smoky flavor, typical low nitro carbonation. I like the smokiness.

Draft at the brewery. Pours a deep brown reddish character with a medium brown head. Flavor is a dry deep malt, almost like Guinness, but better. Flavor is a dry sweetness. Medium body with a lingering dry stout character. Interesting, but Ive never been a Guinness fan, so not my favorite Russian river.

Draft - Dark roast malts, espresso and chocolate. Jet black with a creamy light brown head. Roast malts and chocolate, with the slightest bitterness that ends quickly. Finish is roasty, great for the ABV.

Tap. Long lasting dark tan head, jet black body. Nose is light roasted coffee, dry maltiness, slight toast, and a bit of cocoa powder. Flavor has a nice chocolate tone with roasted and toasty maltiness, and finishes dry. Nitro delivery provides the soft, creamy light body. Easy drinking

On tap at Russian River, pours a near-black with an amber tinge and a creamy tan head. Aroma is very dry, bringing out oats and some lightly toasted malt. Flavour is surprisingly robust and flavourful for a nitro dry stout, with smooth oats and unsweetened cocoa. Very smooth and creamy on the palate, without any lingering bitterness or metallic quality that is common with the style. Great one.

On tap at the brewery in Santa Rosa, pours a rich dark black color with a creamy java head. Nose is chocolate and oatmeal and pleasant. Taste is creamy with deep chocolate and oatmeal. Finish is dry, and short. Quaff Score 7 / 10

On tap nitro at Russian River Brewery in Santa Rosa. Pours black with a creamy light tan head and aroma of sweet cocoa. Taste is smooth and creamy, nice sweet chocolate and cocoa with burnt roasted malt and bitter coffee notes leading to a creamy, chocolatly finish. Delicious brew
Pours black. Not a powerful aroma, bread and caramel. Good flavor, roasty, smokey flavors and a little caramel sweetness. Not an overpowering stout, but enjoyable.
Rated from backlog. Aroma is roasted with some coffee, hints of licorice and English toffee. Flavour is rather roasted with some oeat and coffee. A bit light palate.

Alla spina al brewpub. Forse la birra che ho meno apprezzato di Russian River, forse perchè il livello delle altre è eccelso ma questa mi è sembrata mancare di carattere. Una stout tutto sommato normale.
Tap. Dark, dark brown with a tan head. Smells espresso, toasted malt, chocolate and sweet malt. Taste is toasted malt, sweet malt, espresso and choclate. Light bitter. Light body.
On tap, brewpub sampler. Soft creamy body. Light toasted, biscuit notes, watery middle. Some woody and hoppy finishing elements, though undynamic. Lingering milky soft sweetness.
tap- Pour is clear brownish with light tan head..Nose is sweetness, lactose, coffee, soft..Taste is light, chocolate, coffee, spices, lactose, light bitterness
Very smooth and balanced brew. Plenty of malt flavor. Ive had better but it rates in the top half.

Draught @ Russian River Brewing, Santa Rosa, CA
Pours roasted malt, chocolate and caramel. Taste is light sweet and light to medium bitter with a roasted chocolate and dry finish. Body is light to medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.

On tap at the brewpub. it pours a reddish brown body, clear, and topped by a light beige head. Curtains. The aroma is on the dark malty side, with coffee, bonfire notes and some dried fruits. Full body, pleasant carbonation, with flavors of roasted malts, some nuts and dried fruits. Lasting finish. Not impressive, but tasteful anyway. 130806

On tap at brewpub. Pours dark brown with a small off white head. Aroma of malt, some roasted notes and berries. Flavor is sweet and rotated with some chocolate and grains. Medium body, average carbonation.

On tap at brewpub on 062013. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma has roasted notes of coffee and chocolate. Taste has roasted notes, light bitter and a hint of red berry sweetness. Light body with a light and smooth carbonation, finish is very light with a touch of bitter chocolate.
Has a pretty good aroma. Has a dry coffee taste, very solid. I have had a few too many to judge well.

Not the best stout I've ever had. Fairly boring for a stout. I wouldn't turn one down though.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
tap- Pour is clear brownish with light tan head..Nose is sweetness, lactose, coffee, soft..Taste is light, chocolate, coffee, spices, lactose, light bitterness

Pours black with low tan head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate malt, brown sugar, cream, vanilla. Taste is milk chocolate sweet and coffee bitter. Lingering bitter finish. Light yet creamy body with soft carbonation. Great, especially considering the ABV.
Had on draft at the brewery. Notes of coffee, roasted malts, caramel, slight acidity. Tasty stout.

pint at  Brewpub. om aroma. sweet. roasty. chocolate, coffee. dark orange brown color. nice head and.lace. bitter flavor. ljght body, smooth mouthfeel. roasty finish. nice sessioable stout. not much different from Victory s irish stout. fine for st Patricks...
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: On nitrogen at the brewpub. Gorgeous clear brown pour with a silky creamy head. Aroma is light roast and a little ash. Coffee. Flavor is similar. Nicely roasted bitter without being acrid.  Really nice easy drinking stout.

On tap at the brewpub. Pour is clear brown with a light red hue, tan head and great lacing. Roasty, chocolatey, light coffee, dry, slightly woody, graham crackers, and vanilla in the aroma. Taste is roasty, coffee, cocoa, light biscuit, toasted bread, marshmallows, and grass with a lingering chocolate aftertaste. Medium body with soft carbonation. Nice foreign stout.

Pours deep mahogany brown with some red tones and a nice creamy light brown head leaving lacing. Aroma is roasted malty bready some coffee a bit ashy dry. Flavor is dry ashy fruity roasted chocolate acidy; excellent session stout. Good dry fruity roasted finish.
Nice light balance in this stout.. nothing to strong standing flavors. Just a good rosary coffee balance.

Tap @ RR. Black pour with a thick tan nitro head and a lovely cascade. Nose is damped due to the head, but is lightly roasted. Medium-heavy body and light, very fine carbonation. Dark roasted malt, light chocolate and toffee, and a finishing tartness (?acidulated malt). Ive been trying to do this and failing. Maybe a bit more biscuit needed, but very good and better than Guinness by a ways.

Pours jet black with a thick tan head. Good lacing. Tastes of coffee and chocolate. Very drinkable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at brewpub, Pours a dark black with a beige head. Very smooth light easy stout with a bitterness,
Black with creamy head. Thin body. Aroma and flavour of heavily roasted malts and light smokiness.
Black classic looking dry irish stout on nitro. Taste is burnt chocolate and some nice coffee flavours. Really smooth and a good session stout!
Pitch black with a thick tan head. This nitro charged ale lacks complexity. Dry, roasted, and boring.

Draft in a sampler at the brewpub, and some sips stolen from my wifes glass. Pours a dark brown color with some amber highlights on the edges and a creamy beige head. Notes of chocolate, toast, nuts, and some smoky, peaty notes as well. Light-bodied, with a super dry mouthfeel and quick finish. Almost a bit watery. A bit of a disappointment for someone who likes stouts as much as I do.

Brown black pour with a ton if brown head. Lots of carbonation?  Good stout. Not too much different than guiness in my opinion.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draught @ the brewpub, Santa Rosa. Rated on 20.10.2012.
Pours a black colour with a very creamy beige head. Aroma of roasted malts and toasted bread. Flavour of roasted malts, grassy hops, coal and cold coffee. Very smooth mouthfeel and soft carbonation. Finishes dry and malty. Overall very balanced.

Dark black in color... Aroma of roasted malts... Flavor is roasted malts, balanced with nice hop finish... Solid

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Russian River. Super dark brown/ black with a beige head. Chocolate and caramel with hints of toffee and bakers chocolate. Basically what Guinness should be. Creamy body with a savory milk chocolate finish.

Tap (nitrogen). Pours clear deep brown with a tint of red. Small brown head that dissipates with nice lacing. Aroma is of coffee and dark roasted malt, with hints of dark chocolate. Flavor is the same, lightly coffee bitter and medium sweet. Body is a little thin for my taste, but the overall flavor profile is impressive for a 4% ABV beer.

Good as pitch with creamy beige curtains. Sweet drinking chocolate aroma; fine-sieved cocoa heavy with coal and grilled veg on the palate. Slightly lush and again very balanced.

1 oz pour at Russian River. 

A - Deep dark beer. 2 finger head that sticks around.

S - Nutty and some burnt coffee notes. Roasted almonds and herbs

T - Roasted and warm. Peanut butter and honey. Vanilla 

M - Medium body. 

O - Drinkable considering the ABV. Not a lot of complexity.

Draught @ the brewpub. Rated on 21.07.2012
Aroma is roasted with some coffee, hints of licorice and English toffee. Flavour is rather roasted with some oeat and coffee. A bit light palate and an English feeling here.

Draught @ Brewpub, Santa Rosa.
Rated on 20120721.
Pours deep dark ruby red color with small head. Aroma of chocolate, malts and mild fruits. Flavor of chocolate, malts, ripe fruits. Smooth creamy palate.
3313

Tap at the brewpub-Ok, i get it, they are trying to make a stout for those US Guiness drinkers.  However, no matter how you do it, Nitro taps kill beers!!!!  Pours deep brown with a fizzy kacki head that was smooth.  nose is smokey, nutty and lite baking chocolate.  flavors are roasty, smokey, tobacco and lite burnt bitters.  i hate the soft body that nitro does to these beers-just makes me mad!  However, this beer would suck on a normal tap due to the huge roasted notes on the finish, which would be accented on any normal CO2 tap.  decent however, not my thing.
Tap. Nice head with excellent duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are smooth roastes malt, licorice, milky chocolate and hops. Nice dry finish.

Aroma: roast malts and coffee, mellow creamy sweetness.  Pours black, thick tan head with excellent retention, tons of lacing.  Smooth coffee flavor, nice roast profile, creamy and very smooth, mild bitterness, toasty and slightly sweet malts.  Light to medium body, very smooth texture.

A - pours opaque cola brown with high elasticlly thick fluffy tan head. Aggressive lacing . S - coffee, bakers chocolate, burned malts up front. Chalky. M - pretty light bodied. Creamy mf. Lingering dry watery bitter coffee/burned malts. T - bitter coffee, bakers chocolate and burned malts throughout. Very chalky. Notes of smoke and vegetal fresh malts end. O - pretty good very light stout. 6
Tap at Russian River. Dark cola pour with a huge frothy cream head - nitro. Roasted malts in the nose. Creamy palate. Taste is roasty and somewhat bitter.
Tasted as one of a flight of 17 with Kaetchen at RR. Slight smoked bacon aroma, surprisingly little flavor, kind of watery, dryish finish.

2 oz. sample draft at the brew pub in Santa Rosa, California.  The pour is cloudy black brown with a nitro light tan head.  The aroma is roast char malt, along with a light vanilla sweetness.  The taste is soft roast malt, light sweet vanilla, mineral gypsum, and a dry finish. The palate is medium bodied, nitro carbonation, dry mineral finish.  Nice clean stout.  If this was my local (can you imagine?) I would mix this beer in frequently.

Black pour, creamy tan head.  Damn this is nice.  Loaded with good espresso notes, roast and cocoa.  Flavor is all coffee and roast and I love it.  Someone tell Bryan Myron to not drink so damn much of it next time.  On tap at RR.
UPDATED: APR 29, 2012 Pretty good stout by RR. you should have seen this drink in action, hell yeah!

On nitro at Russian River. Deep cola ruby pour looking black in the nonic pint. Nitrogen provides a thick, Guinness cream foam with huge retention and sheets of nitro lace. Nose is essentially absent as expected in style. Perhaps twang of lemon and acidic coffee. Taste is quite hoppy for style with lemon tea up front and bitter cocoa powder in the back end. Watery body as expected for gravity. Nicely sessionable though not a big step up from Guinness and certainly not as good as the Aud Blonde so....why bother? 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Great stout. Has a dry finish for a stout. Dark malt taste nice black color. Great beer

Draft @ brewpub. Pours lovely black with tan creamy head. Milk chocolate aroma is smooth but subdued. The palate is creamy, and oh-so-soft due to the nitro, which of course kills so much of the beers natural character. However, the lingering roast in finish comes through just fine. Has a slight acidity for balance and the ABV is in the right pocket. I prefer the porter overall but this is just fine.

On Tap at RRBC. The color is pure black. The nitro helps bring some coffee aroma out. The taste however seems to be a bit watery. I enjoyed it overall, it is a very easy to drink stout. However it did taste a bit like watered down coffee.
Another beer in the sampler.  Aroma of chocolate and coffee.  Roasted malt in the flavor, coffee, chocolate.  Good flavor for a low alcohol dry stout.
On tap at the brewery on a n. california trip.  Nitro.  Aroma of smoke and leather.  Creamy low carbonation.  Coffee and chocolate in the taste.  Good.  7.6

More watery than a stout should be, its deceptive with its color and aroma, but in the end falls short

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Russian River. Pours a dark brown with a creamy body and 1 finger of beige head. Leaves a thick lacing on the glass. Smells of roasted malts and chocolate. Taste confirms the nose, lots of roasted malts and chocolate flavors. Medium bodied stout with a very creamy finish, super smooth on the back of the tongue. Overall a very nice dry stout.

A - Served a dark black color with a finger of creamy chocolate colored head. The head hangs around forever and leaves behind tons of lacing as it finally fades.

S - Aroma is a mix of burnt chocolate malts and earthy hops. There is also some smoke and some coffee mixed in as well.

T - Starts off withe a lots of burnt chocolate malt flavors with a bit of herbal hops. Through the middle, the herbal hops grow a bit alongside some lactose sweetness and some smoke. The finish is a mix of burnt dark chocolate and a bit of smoke and coffee that linger.

M - Medium bodied with mild carbonation. The beer felt extremely smooth with a nice dry mouthfeel from all the burnt flavors.

D - Very drinkable. The flavors had great depth and richness and the mouthfeel was excellent. The addition of the hop flavor really worked well here.
Draft at RR... Medium brown body, great lacing on a light tan head... Light nose but great, tobacco with roast chocolate... Taste is great, smokey with chocolate... Great feel, crushable

On tap at the brew pub, served in a tasting glass. Pours dark mahogany with a moderate, fine tan head. The head fades very slowly, leaving moderate fine lace. The nose has tobacco and roasted malts, with earth and herbs. The flavour starts out lightly bitter-sweet and becomes slightly more bitter. Notes of coffee and burnt notes appear and carry into a longish roast malt finish. On the palate, it is medium in body with a milky smooth nitrogenated texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is not a bad stout with roast malt and tobacco notes. The body is thinner than it should be. 2011-06-09

Served on nitro at RR (notes).  Pours dark brown with a fine medium sized beige head.  The aroma was roasted malts with a splash of black coffee.  The flavor had roasted malts, coffee and a hint of dark chocolate.  Body was lighter than I like with a smooth presentation from the nitro.  A quality brew for sure, but give me their sours.
On nitro tap. Notes of caramel, smoke, soured beer, wood, black rye bread. Watery.

Served on nitro I believe at Russian River. The appearance is a beautiful black brown with a medium creamy brown head. The aromas are rich with chocolate, medium roasted malts, and a touch of cappuccino. The flavors melded beautifully with a great dark chocolate, medium to deep roasted malts. Very strong well done flavors. The mouth is creamy and medium-full bodied. What a great dry stout, one of the best. I with RR would do some more stouts after this experience.

On tap at the brewery.  This beer has aromas of toffee, coffee, and chocolate.  The appearance is  a nice dark brown with a substantial and lasting tan head.  This pour was on nitro, so the brew was velvety smooth.  The tastes were coffee, and roasted malts that were very tasty.  The beer was very drinkable and medium bodied with a nice long coffee finish.  Overall, this beer is a good lightner dry stout that is very drinkable, especially for a stout.
On tap at RR.  This stout was kinda watery with burnt malt and tobacco flavors.  To be honest, I was a little disappointed.
draft at Russian River, dark cascading pour, creamy tan head,  medium body, little light. Roasted/ toasted maltiness both in flavor & aroma. good flavor, decent & well done for the style
Reddish black pour with tan head. Aroma was mild roast and chocolate characteristics. Taste is very dry and roasty with nice carbonation. Very good for such a low ABV stout. Session STOUT!!!!!!!

12/10/10 notes:  On tap, brewpub sampler. Soft creamy body. Light toasted, biscuit notes, watery middle. Some woody and hoppy finishing elements, though undynamic. Lingering milky soft sweetness. Reminds me of Triumph Oatmeal Stout.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2011 Sample at the brewpub. Pours brownish-black with a medium thin and compact tan head that burns away slowly. Patchy lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malt and coffee. Medium, creamy body with flavors of roasted malt, chocolate and mild coffee. The finish is roasty with a light coffee aftertaste. Decent overall.

Russian river ovl stout off the nitro... Aroma of light chocolate and  
roast. Pretty mild...Flavors are soft and watery with a fluffy  
mouthfeel. Light chocolate and roast.
6/4/7/3/13
Tap at the source.  Dark brown color, thick brown head.  Aroma of milk chocolate.  Taste is smooth milk chocolate, light body.  Decent.

Nitro-tap at the RR Brewery in August 2009.

A: Pours a very dark brown with a nice off-white head.

S: Dark roasted malts and a little bit of coffee character.

T: Tastes somewhat dry with the coffee and roasted malt--not getting too much complexity from this one, and something is a little off in the balance, although I cant say exactly what.

M: The best part of this brew--minimal carbonation to go with a smooth creaminess.

D: The mouthfeel is really nice, but there was really nothing special about the taste of this one.

Serving type: nitro-tap

Reviewed on: 10-04-2009

Draft. A pitch black beer with a dark brown shine under a thin brown head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt as well as a bit of soy sauce. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of roasted malt as well as light notes of sulphur, leading to a dry and bitter finish. The body is a bit thin.
Dark Brown, off white head.  Roasted dark malt nicely hopped balanced.  Very drinkable.  On draft.
On nitro at the brewpub.  Dark brown pour, creamy nitro head.  Roasted malt, light chocolate sweetness, and caramel.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Pretty standard dry stout.

Had on tap at RR brewpub.  OVL stands for Old Vic Loyalist, the name of the dive bar that previously inhabited the space that RR brewpub now stands.  A nice nitrogen stout, the beer pours a dark brown/black with good nitrogen head.  Aroma is mostly coffee, caramel, and sugar with a hint of chocolate and malts.  Taste is more of the same - mostly coffee and caramel, finish is strong and bitter.  Lots of roasted malts and a nice balance and easy drinking with the nitrogen.
On tap at RR.  Aroma of Roasty malt and some creaminess. Roasty flavor, some chocolate, creamy finish.
At brewery.  Pours opaque.  Much coffee roast, cocoa, and bitterness.  Pretty typical stout.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours with a deep brown body and a large tan-brown head. Aroma of coffee, roast, fudge and earth. Taste is earth, light sour tinge, light earth, smoke and roast. Watery, intro mouthfeel. Very much the epitome of a perfectly executed dry stout.

On tap at the brewpub.  Dark brown to black with strong tan/brown nitro head.  Nose is dry chocolate and light malt sweetness.  Taste is sharp and even.  Cocoa, bit of sweet chocolate and coffee.  Bitter but clean finish.  Not much aftertaste lingering.

Pours dark brown with a tan head. The aroma is roasted coffee beans and dark bitter chocolate. The flavor is very roasted with a slightly ashy finish. A little watery on the palate. A pretty standard dry nitro stout.

I had this as part of the 16 beer sampler (enjoyed with my future wife..couldnt do it all alone).  Appearance is pure black with a very creamy head.  This is a Chocolate bomb in aroma & taste, also tasted a bit of cocoa.  Very very good dry stout, the most "desserty" Ive had from this style.
Pours a dark reddish brown. Smoky meats and coffee on the nose - very smoky / roasty. Dry, with very little sweetness.
Nitro pour. Black, one-inch head, excellent lacing. Dark chocolate aroma, super smooth, very dry. Great!
On tap at the brewpub.  Nitro, making for a creamy head on black.  Coffee roast aroma, flavour.  Chocolate.  A little watery, and can only drink so much of it.
Draught at the brewpub. Absolutely everything I love about a good dry stout. Roasted malts, nuttiness, bitter baking chocolate, light coffee and not over-the-top ABV. A very well done classic.

Dark black with a very dark brown head.  Tight lace.  The aroma is very roasty with a nice soft herbal character.  A touch of acidity on the palate and it finishes incredibly dry.  Soft lingering mix of earthiness and roastiness.  Nice roasty finish.

The beer looks great. Its a very dark brown or black with a head that just refuses to dissipate. The nose was mostly malt but a bit weak. There were some lurking coffee and chocolate notes in the aroma. The beer delivered more taste than the smell indicated. It has a light roasted malt flavor than is better balanced and more interesting than most beers of this style. The beer was still somewhat light-bodied for me. Its a drinkable stout with a great flavor and a light body.

On draft at Russian River Brewing (Santa Rosa, CA): A fluffy khaki head tops a dark brown/black body with red see-through edges. Roasted malts take the aroma with some dark chocolate, earthy hops, black coffee, and burnt wheat toast. Flavors of nice burnt malts, roasty caramel sweetness, some earthy grain and slight hop presence. Thin mouthfeel (lacks robustness- but then afterwards found out it was a dry stout). Creamy throughout. Bitter dry coffee bean finish. Drinkability: Pretty average. Pairing: Classic with oysters. Rebuy: Yeah. #355 on 31032010, DG.

On tap at the brewery/pub on PtY release 10.  Pours black with a tan head.  Nose is of ash and coffee.  Taste is of coffee and ash.  Mouthfeel is thin and dry.  Too thin for a stout.  Overall, ok, but not anything special.

Tap at Russian River. For fucks sake, I didnt realize this was a dry stout. I am sorry I intensely dislike this style of beer. I am going to attempt to be indifferent, and rate it just like anything else. Fluffy tan head that doesnt fade away. Black opaque body. The beer LOOKS pretty good. This style of beer never looks bad. Subtle smoke aroma with some roast, coffee, and chocolate. Quite the complex aroma for the style. As always, watered down and heavily roasted flavor. Some sweet chocolate is barely coming through, along with a touch of coffee. Honestly, the roast flavor and watery flavor are just boring and getting tiring to try. Epic fail on this. No wonder Russian River doesnt bottle this garbage.

A: A great looking beer. The pour is black with a thick off-white head that leaves amazing lacing on the glass.

S: The smell is roasted malt, coffee, a bit of chocolate, and maybe some toasted nut aroma.

T: The flavors are just about what you would expect from the nose. The roasted malt and coffee are the most dominant, but the light chocolate and nuttiness come through to provide a nice combination.

M: The beer is a little thin for what I like in a stout, but still has a decently creamy or silky texture. The carbonation is very minimal, but thats what you expect from a nitro beer.

D: This is a great session/easy drinking stout. The flavors are nice and the alcohol is low, providing a beer that you can easily have several of throughout the night.
On tap at Russian River, nice pour, great head retention. Palate is dry with a clean finish.  Chocolate, coffee are apparent, but lacks any serious palate.  As Jim Carrey said, "Ive had better".

On tap at brewery: Super creamy and smooth on the tongue. Very rich and roasted malts -- flavorful and aromatic. Earthy and wholesome beer, with a fresh, "homebrewed" quality to it. Great balance and interplay between sweet chocolate and bitter grass. Very tasty stout.
Draught at Russian River.  Very Irish Stout-ish. Creamy. No overpowering coffee or roast flavor. But enjoyable.

I realize this is a cop-out but the commercial description is true.  IT is a true irish stout.  Good roastiness, not overly complex flavour-wise but it is quite tasty.  It is very clean and drinkable.  Nice brew

On tap at the brewpub.  The look is black with red tinges and has a nice beige tan colored head.  The smell is dry roasted coffee, malts, and toast.  The taste is malts, roasty, coffee, and slight bitterness.
(Draught)  Pours a black body with a medium tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, toasted grain, coffee, and cocoa.  Flavor of roasted malt, coffee, and light licorice with a dry, bitter finish.

A deep dark stout with  a thick dirty chocolate moka head. A pleasant mokacinno aroma, with light herbal hops notes. In mouth, a nice bitter chocolate, dry and powdery, with light metallic hops, light yet good. On tap at brewpub, August 17 2009.

10 ounce sample at the brewery during RBSG.  Roasted and burnt aroma with some light coffee notes present.  Pretty straight forward and pedestrian start.  Mildly transparent dark mahogany body with a tan head that leaves some good lacing.  Pretty roasted, burnt, and chocolatey to start.  Has some light licorice flavors that linger later on.  Pretty average.
On tap. Black and opaque with a rough, beige head. Hard roasted malt aroma. Rather light and watery in body, very hard roasted malts - almost coffee-like - with a fairly malt bitter finish. 110709

Sampled on tap at the brewhouse.  Pours a watery, opaque black with a white, creamy head.  Aroma of roasted malts, some dark fruits, toast.  Flavor was nice, sweet malts, oats, toast, coffee.  Finish is dry.  Super sessionable and very nice for the style.

On tap at the brewpub on 6/30/09. Pours nice dark brown, with little reddish undertones.  Not much going on in aroma, but only hints of coffee and pine.  However, very well balanced with great dry coffee finish.

From tap at the brewpub. Pours dark brown to black with a small tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, light chocolate and coffee accents. Roasted and mild acidic flavoured. Bitter and acidic finish. Simple stout.

On tap at the brewery. Pours black with a creamy beige head. Medium bitterness. Aromas of toasted malts and coffee. Also aromas of very dark chocolate. Light bodied. Very soft carbonation. The finish reminds me of very dark chocolate.

Date: July 08, 2009
Mode: Draft
Source: Brewpub
Appearance: black with creamy tan head
Aroma: big roasted and dark chocolate aroma
Body: light creamy body
Flavor: rich roasted flavor, dark chocolate
Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3.3/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **+/4
Poured very black @ brewery, roasted malts, coffee, little dark chocolate, slight dark fruit.
Draft at the brewpub. Pours black with a thick creamy head. Dry roasted grain aroma. Roasted grain, dry coffee taste with a hint of fruit. Standard dry stout.
Tap at RR. Black body, with a small brown head. Aroma is chocolate, coffee and roasted malt. Flavor is chocolate, coffee and prunes. Thin waterish body.

Pours a dark brown/black. Nose is roasted malts, some coffee, some earthy hops and tasted bread. Flavor is nice burnt malt, roasty caramel sweetness, some earthy grain and slight hop presence. Beautiful creamy mouthfeel. Finishes dry.

Tap at RR. Deep, darkest brown, near black. Aroma pretty mild, smoke and roast coffee. Flavor is smoke chocolate, roast malts, dry and slightly bitter finish. Fairly light mouthfeel for a stout. Decent, nothing outstanding.

Pours black with red highlights.  aroma of coffee, bakers chocolate, and beans.  Flavor of bitter black coffee, cocoa and beans.  Finishes with coffee grounds and burned rye.  Great stuff for a sort of stout Im not fond of.  Light and creamy.  Id have it again.

Dry and Irish indeed.  A nice little stout with a rock-solid stiff, almost nitro-like head.  
After reading some of the other reviews I think it was nitro, which also explains the smoothness.
Hard to tell the color in the dark bar, but it looked jet black with a just browner than tan head.  The flavors were chocolatey and roasted-toasted malts.

On draft as part of the sampler trey at the brewpub. Nice black pour with a moderate tan head and no lacing. Roasty smell and flavor with a creamy mouthfeel and a dry snap of a finish. Not bad, but nothing spectacular.

Tap at the brewpub: Deep brown pour with a creamy, lacing khaki head. Roasted aroma- dark cocoa, some black malt, rounded. Creamy nitro feel on the palate. Nice roasted flavor- mildly charred black malt gives way to a chocolaty character and a wafer like note. The back is more husky and has apparent black malt roast. Developed malt depth for a dry stout. Nice example.

Draught at the brewpub.   Deep, dark brown with a beige head.   Light creamy cocoa aroma.   The flavor is dry and roasty, with some acidic dark malt, and a bitter, dry, and lightly acidic finish.   Light and flat mouthfeel.   On the bitter/acidic side of the style, which makes it interesting, but also still not that great.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2009 On tap at Russian River.  Good for the style (dry Irish stout) but not overly exciting.  Pours black with a frothy tan head.  Roasted malt, coffee and cream on the aroma.  Roasted malt flavor with a little bitter cocoa.  Slight sourness.  Medium palate for the style.  Dry finish.

On tap at Russian River.  Pours a Black color with a creamy lasting head.  Smell is light roastiness and creamines but with some bitterness.  Nice flavor of roast for a nitro beer and not as dull as others can be.  Soft creamy body and soft carbonation.  Not one of my favorites here, but as a nitro stout, one of the better ones Ive had for certain.

Nitro tap at the brewpub. Dark brown color with ruby hilites and a fine tan head. Chocolate aroma. Smooth body with smooth nitro bubbles. Flavor is mostly chocolate to me. Hardly any burnt toast - just as an undertone. Finishes very mellow.

(10/28/08) Draught sample at the brewpub in Santa Rosa.  Very dark brown color with a light brown head. Aroma of coffee with milk-chocolate notes. Sweet flavor with some coffee and some cream. Medium-bodied with the usual nitro mouthfeel.

On tap at the brewpub.  Color was dark brown with a light brown head.  Not only was their some lacing, but a  complete coating of the glass.  Aroma of sweet malt, cocoa, and roasted malt.  Flavor was very nice for the style.  Cocoa, caramel, roasted malt and sweet malt.  Some earthiness.  Good stuff.

Tap at the brewpub. The body was black with a large tan colored head. The aroma was strong coffee with mocha and peanuts. There was also a little bit of caramel. The taste was strong coffee with some dark chocolate. Bits of hay. Decent.
UPDATED: JAN 14, 2009 on tap at RR.  nice light, drinkable, session stout due to the low alcohol and nitro.  Typical roasty, coffee-like flavors.  I would like to see a stronger version for sure.

Traditional yet slightly better than normal stouts.  The malt was strong with coffee and walnut notes.  Nothing amazing, especially after having a goblet of Consecration, but a better than average stout.

Draft @ Russian River.  Pours a dark chocolate-brown color; light brown head with excellent retention and fine-bubbled lacing that sticks.  Lots of toasted malts, milk chocolate, and light smoked meat presence in the aroma; nicely dry.  Medium mouthfeel: milk chocolate, roast, and lightly acidic coffee upfront; just a touch watery on the perimeter; otherwise, a generous dry stout with a touch of smoked meats.  Medium finish: chocolate, roasted malts, and coffee; nicely dry with a touch of smoke.
Tap @ RR. Dark color, creamy dark brown head. Soft coffee aroma. Creamy taste, chocolat, coffee, bit mocha. Bit dry.
On tap @ RR.  Pours a black color with a creamy, tan head.  Big, roasted coffee aroma.  Nutty beginning, burnt toast and malts.  Creamy body, bitter, dry finish.  I’m a sucker for a good stout...

Sampler at the RR Brewpub (Santa Rosa, CA). Surprisingly good. Deep dark ruby over midnight hue with a sizable cocoa head that stuck around pretty far into the tasting. Aromas are a smooth and creamy sweetness with dark malt notes and cocoa wafting in prominently as well. Taste is dark malts, coffee, and touches of dark chocolate. Exceptional lacing. A little light in body, watery, but finishes quite nicely and smooth. Yum. Cheers!

Pours completely black with a nitrogen rich caramel colored head. 
Aroma: Creamy chocolate, caramel, and roasted espresso, and malty deliciousness. 
Flavor: You know the way people rave about Guinness? They way they say it’s rich, creamy, full bodied, while still having a great flavor. Well I never thought that about guinness, but OVL is all that and more. Dark chocolate, roasted malts, bitter hops, creamy smooth caramel, and a nice mellow coffee finish. 
The palate is full while still being thin enough to drink with comfort. Perfect balance of flavors and insanely enjoyable.

On tap at the RR brewpub.  Pours pitch black with a dark beige head.  Nose- dark roasted coffee and chocolate.  Taste-  very dry and roasty with wood and smoky undertones.  The nitro is not overbearing in adding creaminess.  This dry stout is true to its name and is thinner in body than expected.  A real brewing feat.  Low in carbonation and slides down nicely.

On tap @ the brewpub.   Very deepruby with a one finger creamy beige head that lasted as long as all beers on nitro do.  A lot of chocolate with damp wood that isn’t yet musty and underlying roast make up the aroma.  Flavor is chocolatey with light malted milks balls added. The roast is there, but not too strong.  Bitternesss peaked at a 3 in the finish.  Light to medium body with only the slightest tingle of arbonation.  Pretty good stout, despite being on nitro.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: I got a lot of wood and smoke on the nose.  Very roasted, almost burnt malt body with a small smoky piece.  Somewhat sour with a tart and dry finish.

Draught. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, and hazelnuts. Black with a thin head that leaves nice lace. Chocolate acidity up front into a strong nuttiness. Very creamy mouthfeel from nitrogen, a little thin overall. Chocolate lingers in the aftertaste.

~Pours black with creamy brown head. Good lacing.
~Nice creamy coffee and vanilla like scent.
~Taste like a bitter coffee.
~Creamy feel with a bitter finish.
~A Decent stout. Taste is a bit bitter.
on draft at the brewery. Dark pour with toffee/coffee/burnt malt aromas typical of stouts,   Flavor to match, with dry cigarette finish.
Draft at the brewpub.  Black pour, nitro head.  Aroma was heavily roasted malt, some chocolate, a little lactic.  Flavor is the same, dry-hopping in the finish.

On tap at the brewpub during RRs 4th anniversary.

Nearly black in color with a mocha head that lasts throughout the pint. Good lacing too. Aroma is of sweet cocoa powder with a bit of creamed coffee. Flavor is mildly sweet at first but then explodes with roastiness. Charred roast coffee dominates the finish. Mouthfeel is rather flat as nitro beers will tend to exhibit. Quite drinkable.

On tap at the pub. I was a little disappointed by this beer...for some reason I got it in my head that RR could easily make a great stout...I was wrong. Nice roasted dark chocolate nose which was promising. Flavor was chocolate, coffe and a somewhat ashy. The body was thin and finish was rather weak. Too bad.

On tap at the brewpub in Santa Rosa.  Opaque black with a thick, creamy, medium-tan head.  Heavy toasted grain aroma with some lactic characteristics along with coffee and a bit of dark chocolate.  Full dark roasted malt flavor with good hoppiness that follows through into the finish.  Has a surprisingly light body with great mouthfeel from the nitrogen draught--easygoing with a nice grain profile.
Coffee, coffee, coffee.  I felt that this was all about the java.  Slightly toasty, but mostly tasted of coffee.  No head on the small sampler glass, glossy jet black in color, somewhat thin.
On tap at the brewpub.  A straightforward but well-done stout.  Lots of roasted malt in the nose and up front in the flavor.  A dry, smooth finish.
Drank it on tap at the brewery.  Quite disappointed, maybe its not their style.  Pours pitch black, but light bodied.  More like a porter, ashy and smoky and some molasses.

I was at the brewery today and realized I had one of these on my last pass through a couple months ago. They gave me a taste to refresh my memory.  Very black with light tan head. Nose of chocolate, coffee, and fruit.  Medium mouthfeel but very smooth.  Flavor is roasted malts. Dry finish.  Good and easy to drink.
Pours a black color with a light brown head.  Aroma is chocolate, roast, caramel, and plum.  Flavor is roast, chocolate, caramel, and a light roasty finish.

Tap @ Russian River (I love the sound of that).  Poured black with a nice nitro cascade and creamy tan head.  Light roasty malt aroma with a coffee notes.  The flavor was of roasted malt with a coffee finish.  Light creamy body.

1/3/08 with BikesandBeer, 9th Brewery of the trip, 2nd of the Day.  Finally got to come here.  Pours black with a creamy light brown half finger head.  Nose is sweet, with light malt notes.  Tasteis sweet with a chocolate malt flavor.  Not bad.

On tap at Russian River - Darker brown color with a tan head.  Aroma is dry, smoky, and malty with a light bit of coffee and dark chocolate.  Taste is dominated by dry bittersweet/dark chocolate and some coffee.  Smooth on the tongue but somewhat average.  This ones not bad, but the nitro pour does it no favors.  OK stuff that could be a bit more robust.

Dark black to chocolate-brown color with a ridiculously creamy cappuccino-type head.  Honestly one of the most visually appealing beers Ive ever seen.  Aroma is like slightly burnt chocolate chip cookies along with some burnt toast, dark roasted malts, and a bit of coffee.  Flavors lived up to the hype created by the aroma: burnt toast, cookie/biscuit maltiness, dark roasted/burnt malts, a bit of molasses, chocolate, and some coffee.  Palate is smooth, silky, slightly viscous, but with an extremely clean and crisp dry finish.  Maybe a small amount of a residual sweetness/stickiness.  Amazing stuff, I could drink endless amounts of this.

On nitrogen tap at Russian River brewery. Typical brown-black color with maroon edges. I enjoyed the aroma most about this beer, well-mixed bouquet of ground coffee, mixed holiday nuts and chocolate. Flavors are less enticing, balanced nicely but lacking that "umph" and linger in the mouth. A very mellow beer to drink, its great to session with the subdued ABV %. Not bad.

On nitro tap at the Russian River Brewery. It pours black with creamy light brown head. The aroma is mild sweetness, burnt malts and faint coffee. Yum. The flavor starts with highly roasted malts then burnt malts mixed with chocolate malts. This is an excellent combination of malts. It is tasty, mildly sweet and roasty.

Draft. Very dry (nitrogenated) stout, very drinkable.  Coffee roast and chocolate aroma and taste.  Beautiful in the glass.  One of the softest palates on a stout Ive tasted.  Pillowy, gentle, roasted mouthfeel - almost like a latte -- and I dislike coffee drinks immensely.  This was different; this was still beer.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2007 This is a  good stout overall.  It looks great, with a thick, solid dark body and a very thick, rich tan head that lasts and leaves excellent and exceedingly rich lacing.  It starts nice and roasty, with a good stout chocolate-coffee element and fairly full flavour, but then it briefly becomes a little weak and watery (not uncommon in dry stouts, but hardly necessary), before leaving a mixed finish.  On one hand, the finish is a little sweet and has the nice toasty, smokey element of a good stout, but this unfotrunately becomes just a little too harsh, with a faint burnt skunky taste.  This is sitll a very good stout since the skunkiness is not strong enough to ruin it by any means, but it is just strong enough to detract a bit. I get this occasionally, but not often, especially since two blocks away, Third Street Aleworks usually has a better tasting, if less aesthetically pleasing, dry stout on tap.

On Tap at the BP
Black with a good sized mocha colored head. Nice roasyed ans coffee aroma and flavors.  The body is a bit thin but the nitro softens it and the long lingering bitter campfie flavors are nice.

On tap @ the brewery. The smooth aroma was the highlight. It came cold and tasted like smoke. I waited 10 minutes, tried it again, and it tasted more strongly of smoke. I must have had a bad day, or just had too high of expectations, because I liked very few of the beers they had on tap this day, and I tried them all, but very few of their high rated beers were available. Disappointing.....

nitro tap: nearly black with great retention and lacing. Aroma is rich coffee with roast, chocolate, caramel, etc etc. Medium to light body. Well made, but not that interesting. I dont like nitro taps.

Draft at the brewpub. Pours a nice grainy black with the traditional slab of wet cement across the top thanks to a nitro pour. Not too much aroma, a little bit of sweet chocolate malt on top of some nutty grain. A little tiny bit of carb makes it through the nitro, which is lovely. Nice chocolate and grain (biscuity, in a nice way) on the mid-palate, no chalk or ash. The nitro doesnt completely kill the flavor, which makes this one a standout among nitros Ive tried.
On tap at Russian River.  Dark brown with ruby highlights and a creamy tan head.  Chocolate and roasty aroma.  Creamy palate.  Chocolate, coffee, and creamy taste.

Sampled at Russian River in mid-June 2007 (nitro). Dark brown with ruby edges and a light brown head. Very nice, pronounced roasty, chocolately nose. Flavor has notes of roasted malt, mocha/chocolate and light caramel - tasty. The only thing I didnt particularly enjoy was the body; it was on thin side with very light carbonation.

Draught (nitro), Russian River.

Head is fully lasting.
Body is dark brown to black.

Aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain, chocolate, cocoa), with notes of minerals and chalk.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Light to medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation.

Good for being nitro, which typically sucks all life from a beer. Good flavor balance.
(on nitro @ the brewery)black body with a creamy head.very smooth creamy body with hints of roasted malts,chocolate,and coffee.alot like Guinness but much better.

On tap at the brewery; nitrogenated.  Pours a dark creamy, blackish brown color with a thin layer of nitrogenated beige head.  Aroma is a clean, smooth, subdued amalgam of arabian mocha coffee, toasted almonds,  and frothy cream.  It smells inviting, but restrained by the shackles of collapsing nitrogen.  Ill just go ahead and skip the description of the mouthfeel, simply because while not disappointing, N2 is the only fitting descriptor for that experience.  The light, yet complex, flavor profile is astounding.  Dark belgian chocolate, earthy sumatran coffee, and toasted pine nuts flood the tongue with an amazing amount of flavor for the inexpensive price of ABV.  Roasty, nutty, malty, yet light and easy drinking; pairs excellent with the smoked salmon foccacia on the menu, especially considering the lightness of the body makes it refreshing as well.  The black board lists this as having 46 IBUs, which I expected to be overwhelming for a beer of this magnitude, but its quite the contrary.  Supplementary is a much better word - the bitterness of the hops carries a rich minty, earthy flavor on the backend that disguises itself perfectly in between the roasty bitterness of the malts, leaving behind a non-herbal smack of palate cleansing, dry stout goodness.  Excellent.

On tap @ Russian River poured a cloudy brownish black with a lasting creamy tan head. Aromas of roastiness, coffee and bitter chocolate. Palate was light bodied and smooth. Flavors of roasted malt, coffee and bitter chocolate with a smooth lingering roasty bitter finish.

Draught at the brewery. beer is nearly opaque, very dark brown with a large, beige, nitro-fueled, lasting, creamy, clingy head.

The aroma is malty with moderate notes of roasted grain, milk chocolate, coffee, trace note of molasses; Light yeast note of basement.

The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter, trace acidic with a longish, lightly sweet, trace bitter finish. Milky roasty retros.

The body is full, the texture is creamy and the carbonation is lively-soft.

Nitro draft at the brewpub 5/7/07. Very deep brown, with a thick tan head. Roasted coffee aroma, with a bit of saltiness.  NIce roasted malt and coffee flavor, with some hops. well balanced and tasty.

25April07 on tap @ Russian River.  dark black, tan head.  very smoky aroma.  a lot lighter bodied than I expected.  Lots of smoke flavors.  dry and heavier hopped than most stouts.  Leaves a coffee bitterness on the palate.
on tap at the brewery - in September 2006. Pitchblack color, nice chocolate, slight sour milk taste. Roasty nose and taste. Small sticky pillow on top.

Draft at the brewpub. Poured an opaque black color. Head was off white with a bit of lace. Attractive roasty chocolate aroma and flavor. Medium bodied and dry on the tongue with a smooth nitro mouth feel. Good stout.

On tap.  Dark brown body with light foamy head.  Nitro smooths out the body but kills a little of the flavour.  Roasty with some chocolate and espresso.  Nothing strong or rich but a nice flavourful dry stout.
Roasted woody nose, opaque black color, creamy sticky head. Complex deep malt tastes of wood, chocolate and coffee. Smooth going done. An excellent stout.

On tap at the brewery. Aroma is roasty with a coffee bean and chocolate combo thats incredibly interesting. Appearance is black, black and just a little more black with a thick tan head. Flavors are all melded together so well, its nice to drink a stout that doesnt make you feel like you swallowed a watermelon. Creamy smooth with a nice bitter finish that reminded me a little of a good espresso.

Draft.  Deep black color with a chalky tan head.  Rich chocolate aromas with some burnt coffee notes.  A very smooth, dry stout with chocolate, coffee, fruit and maybe even a bit nutty.  Crisp, dry finish.  A great beer.
What guinness should be. Raoasted coffee and mocha notes on a creamy and dry malt body. Clean and quaffable stout that could be consumed all day.

tap at the brewery - Pours dark brown to black with a nice thick head.  The aroma is roast malt and the flavor has that good maltiness with some coffee notes.  Its a little light for a stout, fairly good overall but not great.

On tap at Russian River Brewery. This dark brown ale poured with a generous creamy head. The flavor is initially malty, with a long chalky finish.  A decent stout, but not one of the brewerys better efforts.
Cask conditioned sample at the 06 Real Ale Fest.  Dry, acidic dry start with a light mouthfeel.  Lingering mouthfeel featuring patent malt and subtle sweet chocolate.  Decent stuff.

Cask-conditioned 6/9 @ The San Diego Real Ale Festival (Pizza Port Carlsbad). Pours black with a light brown frothy head. Aroma is dark chocolate and roasted coffee. Has a roasted flavor leaving a mild bitterness in the finish. Drinkable and good but not my favorite Stout.

on cask at PP Real Ale Festival 2006.  pours a clear black color with a medium sized tan head that was very thick in appearance.  Aroma is like charcoal and beer farts (thats the best way i can think to describe it).  Flavor is very porter like, roasty and watered down with mild hop hints that came powering through at the end.  I just really couldnt get past the acidity and nose on this beer to enjoy it.  Not what I look for in a stout at all.
Draft. On nitro. Blackish beer with a beige nitro head. Light roasty and nice chocolate flavor with a bit of acidity. light roasty aroma. Lighter bodied. Easy to drink.

Draft at brewpub.  Lies dark and foreboding in the glass, ebony color with garnet highlights when held to light, and a creamy tannish head.  Rich roasty malts, coffe and hints of chocolate in the aroma.  Flavor is also roasty, dry, dry and dry, bitter dark roasted coffee, charcoal and bakers chocolate.  Milky smooth and full bodied.  Good dry stout.
On tap at the pub. Opaque brown with a tan head. Malty caramel aroma, with a slightly molassy taste.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2006 Draught at the brewpub. Very black with lasting creamy beige head. Strong espresso aroma. Medium dry with soft mouthfeel. An incredible amount of coffee flavour, notes of licorice. Salty bitter finish. Gentle, yet packed with flavour.

I tried this at the hollingshead tasting, and tasted less than my group did, "Because I wasnt feeling a Stout at the moment" I should of had more, a nice brew, mellow, good flavor, but not overpowering, roasted flavor, smooth, would drink anytime. solid.
Draught, at the breweryNear black.  Chocolatey aroma, slightly roasty.  Full body, very mocha-like, with only a hint of roasty dryness.  Creamy body.  Standard stout.

on tap at The Russian River Brewing Company in Santa Rosa, CA. pours a deep mahogany with a milk chocolate medium-sized head that lasts and laces. smell burnt. tastes acrid, like liquid smoke. bitter residue. roasted barly, chocolate and caramel malts. very interesting.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2005 Intense coffee flavor and aroma.  Tasted a little over-roasted to my palate.  Great, rich, dark color.  Not too creamy or too watery, but has a good blended feel going down.  Nice and dry and drinks incredibly smooth.  One of the nicer stouts that I’ve had recently.
Heavy roasted aroma, coffee, unsweetened chocolate, caramel.  Why Nitro though, it kills beers?  Smooth, and nice dry stout.  Much better then anything that you can find at Vons.

On tap @ brewery.  Nice dark body with a creamy tan head.  Fair lacing in rings and other loopy shapes.  Weak aroma.  Smelled of dough, musky and earthy, lightly roasted.  Flavor was similar, if a bit sour and not terribly pleasing for a stout.  Some coffee, nutty character, but not much.  Mouth was pleasant and dry, light creamy carbonation.  A dry stout like Murphys but not as harsh and more agreeable.  Easy drinking.
tasted in santa rosa. quite a nutty, creamy aroma reminded me a little of kahlua. pretty dark, coffeeish, sweet, quite dry, nice stuff
Deep brown.  Creamy light brown head.  Light coffee nose, light creamy  nose overall, with a regular burnt coffee and milk chocolate flavors.  Decent.

Tasted at the 2004 Pizza Port Real Ale Festival. Eclipse black color. Small head. Aroma is chocolate and coffee. Slightly sweet. A medium bodied dry stout. Malts are chocolate and sweet. Slightly spicy hops. Nicely balanced. Very smooth. Nicely roasty and toasty. Small soft and round carbonation. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

This beer was sampled at the San Diego Real Ale Festival 2004 on cask. This beer poured a fairly viscous dark brown color with hints of black and a thin sheath of orangy/tan lacing which lasted roughly 2 minutes. The aroma was very stout-like......cocoa, coffee and a milky vanilla in the nose. The taste is much the same. Very milky chocolateyness in mid-taste which sets it apart from most stouts. Grainy chocolates in the finish, fairly dry and long-lasting. Some hint of hops in the finish, overall a well rounded stout. Vinnie knows how to make a damn good brew!

Cask @ Real Ale Fest
The beer pulls from the cask an onyx color the head thick and tall, the color chocolate brown, the texture creamy with the lace a glutinous sheet to cling mightily to the glass. Nose was sweet chocolate; coffee with a rich toasted grain aroma to end it all, start was ambrosia, rich in malt and the top full and creamy. Finish was gentle in it acidity, the hops perfection, somewhat bittersweet and dry aftertaste, I voted this the hit of the fest at least for me, and just missed by a frog hair of getting some at OBriens, damn well better luck next time.

Dirty cream head with a pitch black body.  Cream, hazelnut, tons of roasted malts and a touch of flowers in the nose.  Smooth rounded flavor with robust coco and coffee notes with just enoughf room for a hint of Bailies.  Dryer mouthfeel then the nose would imply finnishing with more coffee.
cask at the real ale fest at pizza port. light flavor and body, slight lactic tones, a nice drinking stout

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2004 (Cask draft: O'Brien's in San Diego, CA) A stout with a lighter flavor and body than many in the category, and a slight sweetness; Moderately strong dark roasted malt flavor is more toasted than roasted, and the bitterness is fairly mild as well; Somewhat smooth and creamy mouthfeel; The palate is medium bodied and, as expected from the cask, low in carbonation; There is an alcoholic, perhaps a bourbon nose, slightly sweet, very nice; Jet black in color and fully opaque; As the light brown bubbly head settles, it clumps together like curdled milk, very interesting looking, but not a negative characteristic in my opinion; Not much lacing(Draft: Russian River Brewing Co. in Santa Rosa, CA) Second tasting at Vinnie's brewpub was on nitro, but not cask like at O'Brien's, and the result was a drier, somewhat standard Irish stout, though still on the thin side in body

This is a good Guinness clone, only this is much, much better. Soft and dry coffeed texture, lightly Roasted. Decently long finish, could drink a lot of these.

Had on cask at Obriens...This stout pours with a black body topped by a thick, tan head with a good amount of lacing.  The aroma is slightly sweet and malty with a nice roasty note and notes of coffee with a touch of chocolate.  The flavor is great.  Its sweet yet slightly bitter and malty with a nice mocha note and a slight roastiness.  Very smooth, creamy and full bodied.

Had on cask at obriens.... pours a deep brown with an off-white head that didnt last, probably due to the cask.  The flavors seemed watered down with little flavor.  Slight bitter dark chocoalte flavors, but nothing memorable.  I will have to try it again, hopefully not on cask.
